verses.text: Being about to prove that the will, the calling, and the commandment of the Trinity is one, St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:3
verses.text: Ambrose shows that the Spirit called the Church exactly as the Father and the Son did, and proves this by the selection of SS.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:4
verses.text: Paul and Barnabas, and especially by the mission of St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:5
verses.text: Peter to Cornelius.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:6
verses.text: And by the way he points out how in the Apostle's vision the calling of the Gentiles was shadowed forth, who having been before like wild beasts, now by the operation of the Spirit lay aside that wildness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:7
verses.text: Then having quoted other passages in support of this view, he shows that in the case of Jeremiah cast into a pit by Jews, and rescued by Abdemelech, is a type of the slighting of the Holy Spirit by the Jews, and of His being honoured by the Gentiles.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:8
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:9
verses.text: And not only is the operation of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit everywhere one but also there is one and the same will, calling, and giving of commands, which one may see in the great and saving mystery of the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:10
verses.text: For as the Father called the Gentiles to the Church, saying: "I will call her My people which was not My people, and her beloved who was not beloved;" and elsewhere: "My house shall be called a house of prayer for all nations," so, too, the Lord Jesus said that Paul was chosen by Him to call forth and gather together the Church, as you find it said by the Lord Jesus to Ananias: "Go, for he is a chosen vessel unto Me to bear My name before all nations".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:11
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:12
verses.text: As, then, God the Father called the Church, so, too, Christ called it, and so, too, the Spirit called it, saying: "Separate Me Paul and Barnabas for the work to which I have called them".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:13
verses.text: "So," it is added, "having fasted and prayed, they laid hands on them and sent them forth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:14
verses.text: And they, being sent forth by the Holy Spirit, went down to Seleucia".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:15
verses.text: So Paul received the apostleship by the will not only of Christ, but also of the Holy Spirit, and hastened to gather together the Gentiles.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:16
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:17
verses.text: And not only Paul, but also, as we read in the Acts of the Apostles, Peter.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:18
verses.text: For when he had seen in his prayer heaven opened and a certain vessel tied at the four corners, as it were a sheet in which were all kinds of four-footed beasts and wild beasts and fowls of the air, "a voice came to him saying, Arise, Peter, kill and eat.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:19
verses.text: And Peter said, Be it far from me, Lord, I have never eaten anything common or unclean.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:20
verses.text: And again a voice came to him, saying, What God hath cleansed call not thou common.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:21
verses.text: And this was done three times, and the vessel was received back into heaven".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:22
verses.text: And so when Peter was silently thinking over this with himself, and the servants of Cornelius appointed by the Angel had come to him, the Spirit said to him, "Lo, men are seeking thee, rise therefore, and go down and go with them; doubt not, for I have sent thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:23
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:24
verses.text: How clearly did the Holy Spirit express His own power! First of all in that He inspired him who was praying, and was present to him who was entreating; then when Peter, being called, answered, "Lord," and so was found worthy of a second message, because he acknowledged the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:25
verses.text: But the Scripture declares Who that Lord was, for He Whom he had answered spoke to him when he answered.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:26
verses.text: And the following words show the Spirit clearly revealed, for He Who formed the mystery made known the mystery.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:27
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:28
verses.text: Notice, also, that the appearance of the mystery three times repeated expressed the operation of the Trinity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:29
verses.text: And so in the mysteries the threefold question is put, and the threefold answer made, and no one can be cleansed but by a threefold confession.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:30
verses.text: For which reason, also, Peter in the Gospel is asked three times whether he loves the Lord, that by the threefold answer the bonds of the guilt he had contracted by denying the Lord might be loosed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:31
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:32
verses.text: Then, again, because the Angel is sent to Cornelius, the Holy Spirit speaks to Peter: "For the eyes of the Lord are over the faithful of the earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:33
verses.text: Nor is it without a purpose that when He had said before, "What God hath cleansed call not thou common," the Holy Spirit came upon the Gentiles to purify them, when it is manifest that the operation of the Spirit is a divine operation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:34
verses.text: But Peter, when sent by the Spirit, did not wait for the command of God the Father, but acknowledged that that message was from the Spirit Himself, and the grace that of the Spirit Himself, when he said: "If, then, God has granted them the same grace as to us, who was I that I should resist God?"  107.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:35
verses.text: It is, then, the Holy Spirit Who has delivered us from that Gentile impurity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:36
verses.text: For in those kinds of four-footed creatures and wild beasts and birds there was a figure of the condition of man, which appears clothed with the bestial ferocity of wild beasts unless it grows gentle by the sanctification of the Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:37
verses.text: Excellent, then, is that grace which changes the rage of beasts into the simplicity of the Spirit: "For we also were aforetime foolish, unbelieving, erring, serving divers lusts and pleasures.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:38
verses.text: But now by the renewing of the Spirit we begin to be heirs of Christ, and joint-heirs with the Angels".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:39
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:40
verses.text: Therefore the holy prophet David, seeing in the Spirit that we should from wild beasts become like the dwellers in heaven, says, "Rebuke the wild beasts of the wood," evidently signifying, not the wood disturbed by the running of wild beasts, and shaken with the roaring of animals, but that wood of which it is written: "We found it in the fields of the wood".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:41
verses.text: In which, as the prophet said: "The righteous shall flourish as the palm-tree, and shall be multiplied as the cedar which is in Libanus".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:42
verses.text: That wood which, shaken in the tops of the trees spoken of in prophecy, shed forth the nourishment of the heavenly Word.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:43
verses.text: That wood into which Paul entered indeed as a ravening wolf, but went forth as a shepherd, for "their sound is gone out into all the earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:44
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:45
verses.text: We then were wild beasts, and therefore the Lord said: "Beware of false prophets, which come in sheep's clothing, but inwardly are ravening wolves".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:46
verses.text: But now, through the Holy Spirit, the rage of lions, the spots of leopards, the craft of foxes, the rapacity of wolves, have passed away from our feelings; great, then, is the grace which has changed earth to heaven, that the conversation of us, who once were wandering as wild beasts in the woods, might be in heaven.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:47
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:48
verses.text: And not only in this place, but also elsewhere in the same book, the Apostle Peter declared that the Church was built by the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:49
verses.text: For you read that he said: "God, Which knoweth the hearts of men, bare witness, giving them the Holy Spirit, even as also to us; and He made no distinction between us and them, purifying their hearts by faith".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:50
verses.text: In which is to be considered, that as Christ is the Cornerstone, Who joined together both peoples into one, so, too, the Holy Spirit made no distinction between the hearts of each people, but united them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:51
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:52
verses.text: Do not, then, like a Jew, despise the Son, Whom the prophets foretold; for you would despise also the Holy Spirit, you would despise Isaiah, you would despise Jeremiah, whom he who was chosen of the Lord raised with rags and cords from the pit of that Jewish abode.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:53
verses.text: For the people of the Jews, despising the word of prophecy, had cast him into the pit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:54
verses.text: Nor was there found any one of the Jews to draw the prophet out, but one Ethiopian Abdemelech, as the Scripture testifies.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:55
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:56
verses.text: In which account is a very beautiful figure, that is to say, that we, sinners of the Gentiles, black beforehand through our transgressions, and aforetime fruitless, raised from the depth the word of prophecy which the Jews had thrust down, as it were, into the mire of their mind and carnality.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:57
verses.text: And therefore it is written: "Ethiopia shall stretch out her hand unto God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:58
verses.text: In which is signified the appearance of holy Church, who says in the Song of Songs: "I am black and comely, O daughters of Jerusalem;" black through sin, comely through grace; black by natural condition, comely through redemption, or certainly, black with the dust of her labours.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:59
verses.text: So she is black while fighting, is comely when she is crowned with the ornaments of victory.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:60
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:61
verses.text: And fittingly is the prophet raised by cords, for the faithful writer said: "The lines are fallen unto me in pleasant places".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:62
verses.text: And fittingly with rags; for the Lord Himself, when those who had been first invited to the marriage made excuse, sent to the partings of the highways, that as many as were found, both bad and good, should be invited to the marriage.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 10:63
verses.text: With these rags, then, He lifted the word of prophecy from the mire.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:2
verses.text: We shall follow the example of Abdemelech, if we believe that the Son and Holy Spirit know all things.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:3
verses.text: This knowledge is attributed in Scripture to the Spirit, and also to the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:4
verses.text: The Son is glorified by the Spirit, as also the Spirit by the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:5
verses.text: Also, inasmuch as we read that the Father, the Son, and the Spirit say and reveal the same things, we must acknowledge in Them a oneness of nature and knowledge.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:6
verses.text: Lastly, that the Spirit searcheth the deep things of God is not a mark of ignorance, since the Father and the Son are likewise said to search, and Paul, although chosen by Christ, yet was taught by the Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:7
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:8
verses.text: And you, too, shall be Abdemelech, that is, chosen by the Lord, if you raise the Word of God from the depth of Gentile ignorance; if you believe that the Son of God is not deceived, that nothing escapes His knowledge, that He is not ignorant of what is going to be.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:9
verses.text: And the Holy Spirit also is not deceived, of Whom the Lord says: "But when He, the Spirit of Truth, shall come, He shall lead you into all truth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:10
verses.text: He Who says all passes by nothing, neither the day nor the hour, neither things past nor things to come.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:11
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:12
verses.text: And that you may know that He both knows all things, and foretells things to come, and that His knowledge is one with that of the Father and the Son, hear what the Truth of God says concerning Him: "For He shall not speak from Himself, but what things He shall hear shall He speak, and He shall declare unto you the things that are to come".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:13
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:14
verses.text: Therefore, that you may observe that He knows all things, when the Son said: "But of that day and hour knoweth no one, not even the Angels of heaven," He excepted the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:15
verses.text: But if the Holy Spirit is excepted from ignorance, how is the Son of God not excepted?  117.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:16
verses.text: But you say that He numbered the Son of God also with the Angels.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:17
verses.text: He numbered the Son indeed, but He did not number the Spirit also.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:18
verses.text: Confess, then, either that the Holy Spirit is greater than the Son of God, so as to speak now not only as an Arian, but even as a Photinian, or acknowledge to what you ought to refer it that He said that the Son knew not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:19
verses.text: For as man He could [in His human nature] be numbered with creatures Who were created.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:20
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:21
verses.text: But if you are willing to learn that the Son of God knows all things, and has foreknowledge of all, see that those very things which you think to be unknown to the Son, the Holy Spirit received from the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:22
verses.text: He received them, however, through Unity of Substance, as the Son received from the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:23
verses.text: "He," says He, "shall glorify Me, for He shall receive of Mine and shall declare it unto you.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:24
verses.text: All things whatsoever the Father hath are Mine, therefore said I, He shall receive of Mine, and shall declare it unto you".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:25
verses.text: What, then, is more clear than this Unity? What things the Father hath pertain to the Son; what things the Son hath the Holy Spirit also has received.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:26
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:27
verses.text: Yet learn that the Son knows the day of judgment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:28
verses.text: We read in Zechariah: "And the Lord my God shall come, and all the saints with Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:29
verses.text: In that day there shall not be light, but cold and frost, and it shall be one day, and that day is known unto the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:30
verses.text: This day, then, was known unto the Lord, Who shall come with His saints, to enlighten us by His second Advent.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:31
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:32
verses.text: But let us continue the point which we have commenced concerning the Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:33
verses.text: For in the passage we have brought forward you find that the Son says of the Spirit: "He shall glorify Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:34
verses.text: So, then, the Spirit glorifies the Son, as the Father also glorifies Him, but the Son of God also glorifies the Spirit, as we said above.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:35
verses.text: He, then, is not weak who is the cause of the mutual glory through the Unity of the Eternal Light, nor is He inferior to the Spirit, of Whom this is true that He is glorified by the Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:36
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:37
verses.text: And you too shall be chosen, if you believe that the Spirit spoke that which the Father spoke, and which the Son spoke.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:38
verses.text: Paul, in fine, was therefore chosen because he so believed and so taught, since, as it is written, God "hath revealed to us by His Spirit that which eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, nor hath entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:39
verses.text: And therefore is He called the Spirit of revelation, as you read: "For God giveth to those who thus prepare themselves the Spirit of wisdom and revelation, that He may be known".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:40
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:41
verses.text: There is, then, a Unity of knowledge, since, as the Father, Who gives the Spirit of revelation, reveals, so also the Son reveals, for it is written: "No one knoweth the Son save the Father, neither doth any one know the Father save the Son, and he to whom the Son shall will to reveal Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:42
verses.text: He said more concerning the Son, not because He has more than the Father, but lest He should be supposed to have less.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:43
verses.text: And not unfittingly is the Father thus revealed by the Son, for the Son knows the Father even as the Father knows the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:44
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:45
verses.text: Learn now that the Spirit too knows God the Father, for it is written that, "As no one knoweth the things of a man, save the spirit which is in him, so too the things of God no one knoweth save the Spirit of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:46
verses.text: "No one," he says, "knoweth save the Spirit of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:47
verses.text: Is, then, the Son of God excluded? Certainly not, since neither is the Spirit excluded, when it is said: "And none knoweth the Father, save the Son".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:48
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:49
verses.text: Therefore the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit are of one nature and of one knowledge.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:50
verses.text: And the Spirit is not to be numbered with all things which were made by the Son, since He knew the Father, Whom (as it is written) who can know save the Son? But the Holy Spirit knows also.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:51
verses.text: What then? When the totality of created things is spoken of, it follows that the Holy Spirit is not included.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:52
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:53
verses.text: Now I should like them to answer what it is in man which knows the things of a man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:54
verses.text: Certainly that must be reasonable which surpasses the other powers of the soul, and by which the highest nature of man is estimated.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:55
verses.text: What, then, is the Spirit, Who knows the deep things of God, and through Whom Almighty God is revealed? Is He inferior in the fulness of the Godhead Who is proved even by this instance to be of one substance with the Father? Or is He ignorant of anything Who knows the counsels of God, and His mysteries which have been hidden from the beginning? What is there that He knows not Who knows all things that are of God? For "the Spirit searcheth even the deep things of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:56
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:57
verses.text: But lest you should think that He searches things unknown, and so searches that He may learn that which He knows not, it is stated first that God revealed them to us through His Spirit, and at the same time in order that you may learn that the Spirit knows the things which are revealed to us through the Spirit Himself, it is said subsequently: "For who among men knoweth the things of a man, save the  spirit of the man which is in him? so, too, the things of God knoweth no one save the Spirit of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:58
verses.text: If, then, the spirit of a man knows the things of a man, and knows them before it searches, can there be anything of God which the Spirit of God knows not? Of Whom the Apostle said not without a purpose, "The things of God knoweth no one, save the Spirit of God;" not that He knows by searching, but knows by nature; not that the knowledge of divine things is an accident in Him, but is His natural knowledge.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:59
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:60
verses.text: But if this moves you that He said "searcheth," learn that this is also said of God, inasmuch as He is the searcher of hearts and reins.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:61
verses.text: For Himself said: "I am He that searcheth the heart and reins".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:62
verses.text: And of the Son of God you have also in the Epistle to the Hebrews: "Who is the Searcher of the mind and thoughts".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:63
verses.text: Whence it is clear that no inferior searches the inward things of his superior, for to know hidden things is of the divine power alone.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:64
verses.text: The Holy Spirit, then, is a searcher in like manner as the Father, and the Son is a searcher in like manner, by the proper signification of which expression this is implied, that evidently there is nothing which He knows not, Whom nothing escapes.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:65
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:66
verses.text: Lastly, he was chosen by Christ, and taught by the Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:67
verses.text: For as he himself witnesses, having obtained through the Spirit knowledge of the divine secrets, he shows both that the Holy Spirit knows God, and has revealed to us the things which are of God, as the Son also has revealed them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 11:68
verses.text: And he adds: "But we received, not the spirit of this world, but the Spirit which is of God, that we might know the things that are given to us by God, which we also speak, not in persuasive words of man's wisdom, but in manifestation of the Spirit and in the power of God".

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:2
verses.text: After proof that the Spirit is the Giver of revelation equally with the Father and the Son, it is explained how the same Spirit does not speak of Himself; and it is shown that no bodily organs are to be thought of in Him, and that no inferiority is to be supposed from the fact of our reading that He hears, since the same would have to be attributed to the Son, and indeed even to the Father, since He hears the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:3
verses.text: The Spirit then hears and glorifies the Son in the sense that He revealed Him to the prophets and apostles, by which the Unity of operation of the Three Persons is inferred; and, since the Spirit does the same works as the Father, the substance of each is also declared to be the same.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:4
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:5
verses.text: It has then been proved that like as God has revealed to us the things which are His, so too the Son, and so too the Spirit, has revealed the things of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:6
verses.text: For our knowledge proceeds from one Spirit, through one Son to one Father; and from one Father through one Son to one Holy Spirit is delivered goodness and sanctification and the sovereign right of eternal power.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:7
verses.text: Where, then, there is a manifestation of the Spirit, there is the power of God, nor can there be any distinction where the work is one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:8
verses.text: And therefore that which the Son says the Father also says, and that which the Father says the Son also says, and that which the Father and the Son say the Holy Spirit also says.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:9
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:10
verses.text: Whence also the Son of God said concerning the Holy Spirit: "He shall not speak from Himself," that is, not without the participation of the Father and Myself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:11
verses.text: For the Spirit is not divided and separated, but speaks what He hears.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:12
verses.text: He hears, that is to say, by unity of substance and by the property of knowledge.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:13
verses.text: For He receives not hearing by any orifices of the body, nor does the divine voice resound with any carnal measures, nor does He hear what He knows not; since commonly in human matters hearing produces knowledge, and yet not even in men themselves is there always bodily speech or fleshly hearing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:14
verses.text: For "he that speaketh in tongues," it is said, "speaketh not to men but to God, for no one heareth, but in the Spirit he speaketh mysteries".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:15
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:16
verses.text: Therefore if in men hearing is not always of the body, do you require in God the voices of man's weakness, and certain organs of fleshly hearing, when He is said to hear in order that we may believe that He knows? For we know that which we have heard, and we hear beforehand that we may be able to know; but in God Who knows all things knowledge goes before hearing.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:17
verses.text: So in order to state that the Son is not ignorant of what the Father wills, we say that He has heard; but in God there is no sound nor syllable, such as usually signify the indication of the will; but oneness of will is comprehended in hidden ways in God, but in us is shown by signs.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:18
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:19
verses.text: What means, then, "He shall not speak from Himself"? This is, He shall not speak without Me; for He speaks the  truth, He breathes wisdom.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:20
verses.text: He speaks not without the Father, for He is the Spirit of God; He hears not from Himself, for all things are of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:21
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:22
verses.text: The Son received all things from the Father, for He Himself said: "All things have been delivered unto Me from My Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:23
verses.text: All that is the Father's the Son also has, for He says again: "All things which the Father hath are Mine".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:24
verses.text: And those things which He Himself received by Unity of nature, the Spirit by the same Unity of nature received also from Him, as the Lord Jesus Himself declares, when speaking of His Spirit: "Therefore said I, He shall receive of Mine and shall declare it unto you".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:25
verses.text: Therefore what the Spirit says is the Son's, what the Son hath given is the Father's.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:26
verses.text: So neither the Son nor the Spirit speaks anything of Himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:27
verses.text: For the Trinity speaks nothing external to Itself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:28
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:29
verses.text: But if you contend that this is an argument for the weakness of the Holy Spirit, and for a kind of likeness to the lowliness of the body, you will also make it an argument to the injury of the Son, because the Son said of Himself: "As I hear I judge," and "The Son can do nothing else than what He seeth the Father doing".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:30
verses.text: For if that be true, as it is, which the Son said: "All things which the Father hath are Mine," and the Son according to the Godhead is One with the Father, One by natural substance, not according to the Sabellian falsehood; that which is one by the property of substance certainly cannot be separated, and so the Son cannot do anything except what He has heard of the Father, for the Word of God endures forever, nor is the Father ever separated from the operation of the Son; and that which the Son works He knows that the Father wills, and what the Father wills the Son knows how to work.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:31
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:32
verses.text: Lastly, that one may not think that there is any difference of work either in time or in order between the Father and the Son, but may believe the oneness of the same operation, He says: "The works which I do He doeth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:33
verses.text: And again, that one may not think that there is any difference in the distinction of the works, but may judge that the will, the working, and the power of the Father and the Son are the same, Wisdom says concerning the Father: "For whatsoever things He doeth, the Son likewise doeth the same".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:34
verses.text: So that the action of neither Person is before or after that of the Other, but the same result of one operation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:35
verses.text: And for this reason the Son says that He can do nothing of Himself, because His operation cannot be separated from that of the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:36
verses.text: In like manner the operation of the Holy Spirit is not separated.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:37
verses.text: Whence also the things which He speaks, He is said to hear from the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:38
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:39
verses.text: What if I demonstrate that the Father also hears the Son, as the Son too hears the Father? For you have it written in the Gospel that the Son says: "Father, I thank Thee that Thou heardest Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:40
verses.text: How did the Father hear the Son, since in the previous passage concerning Lazarus the Son spoke nothing to the Father? And that we might not think that the Son was heard once by the Father, He added: "And I knew that Thou hearest Me always".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:41
verses.text: Therefore the hearing is not that of subject obedience, but of eternal Unity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:42
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:43
verses.text: In like manner, then, the Spirit is said to hear from the Father, and to glorify the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:44
verses.text: To glorify, because the Holy Spirit taught us that the Son is the Image of the invisible God, and the brightness of His glory, and the impress of His substance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:45
verses.text: The Spirit also spoke in the patriarchs and the prophets, and, lastly, the apostles began then to be more perfect after that they had received the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:46
verses.text: There is therefore no separation of the divine power and grace, for although "there are diversities of gifts, yet it is the same Spirit; and diversities of ministrations, yet the same Lord; and diversities of operations, yet the same God Who worketh all in all".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:47
verses.text: There are diversities of offices, not severances of the Trinity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:48
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:49
verses.text: Lastly, it is the same God Who worketh all in all, that you may know that there is no diversity of operation between God the Father and the Holy Spirit; since those things which the Spirit works, God the Father also works, "Who worketh all in all".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:50
verses.text: For while God the Father worketh all in all, yet "to one is given through the Spirit the word of wisdom; to another the word of knowledge, according to the same Spirit; to another faith, in the same Spirit; to another the gift of healings, in the one Spirit; to another the working of miracles; to another prophecy; to another discerning of spirits; to another divers kinds of  tongues; to another the interpretation of sayings; but all these worketh one and the same Spirit, dividing to each one as He will".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:51
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:52
verses.text: There is then no doubt but that those things which the Father worketh, the Spirit worketh also.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:53
verses.text: Nor does He work in accordance with a command, as he who hears in bodily fashion, but voluntarily, as being free in His own will, not the servant of the power of another.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:54
verses.text: For He does not obey as being bidden, but as the giver He is the controller of His own gifts.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:55
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:56
verses.text: Consider meanwhile whether you can say that the Spirit effects all things which the Father effects; for you cannot deny that the Father effects those things which the Holy Spirit effects; otherwise the Father does not effect all things, if He effects not those things which the Spirit also effects.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:57
verses.text: But if the Father also effects those things which the Spirit effects, since the Spirit divides His operations, according to His own will, you must of necessity say, either that what the Spirit divides He divides according to His own will, against the will of God the Father; or if you say that the Father wills the same that the Holy Spirit wills, you must of necessity confess the oneness of the divine will and operation, even if you do it unwillingly, and, if not with the heart, at least with the mouth.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:58
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:59
verses.text: But if the Holy Spirit is of one will and operation with God the Father, He is also of one substance, since the Creator is known by His works.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:60
verses.text: So, then, it is the same Spirit, he says, the same Lord, the same God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:61
verses.text: And if you say Spirit, He is the same; and if you say Lord, He is the same; and if you say God, He is the same.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:62
verses.text: Not the same, so that Himself is Father, Himself Son, Himself Spirit [one and the selfsame Person]; but because both the Father and the Son are the same Power.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 12:63
verses.text: He is, then, the same in substance and in power, for there is not in the Godhead either the confusion of Sabellius nor the division of Arius, nor any earthly and bodily change.

chapters.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:2
verses.text: Prophecy was not only from the Father and the Son but also from the Spirit; the authority and operation of the latter on the apostles is signified to be the same as Theirs; and so we are to understand that there is unity in the three points of authority, rule, and bounty; yet need no disadvantage be feared from that participation, since such does not arise in human friendship.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:3
verses.text: Lastly, it is established that this is the inheritance of the apostolic faith from the fact that the apostles are described as having obeyed the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:4
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:5
verses.text: Take, O sacred Emperor, another strong instance in this question, and one known to you: "In many ways and in divers manners, God spake to the fathers in the prophets".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:6
verses.text: And the Wisdom of God said: "I will send prophets and apostles".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:7
verses.text: And "To one is given," as it is written, "through the Spirit, the word of wisdom; to another, the word of knowledge, according to the same Spirit; to another faith, in the same Spirit; to another, the gift of healings, in the one Spirit; to another, the working of miracles; to another, prophecy".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:8
verses.text: Therefore, according to the Apostle, prophecy is not only through the Father and the Son, but also through the Holy Spirit, and therefore the office is one, and the grace one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:9
verses.text: So you find that the Spirit also is the author of prophecies.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:10
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:11
verses.text: The apostles also said: "It seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:12
verses.text: And when they say, "It seemed good," they point out not only the Worker of the grace, but also the Author of the carrying out of that which was commanded.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:13
verses.text: For as we read of God: "It pleased God;" so, too, when it is said that, "It seemed good to the Holy Spirit," one who is master of his own power is portrayed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:14
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:15
verses.text: And how should He not be a master Who speaks what He wills, and commands what He wills, as the Father commands and the Son commands? For as Paul heard the voice saying to him, "I am Jesus, Whom thou persecutest," so, too, the Spirit forbade Paul and Silas to go into Bithynia.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:16
verses.text: And as the Father spake through the prophets, so, too, Agabus says concerning the Spirit: "Thus saith the Holy Spirit, Thus shall the Jews in Jerusalem bind the man, whose is this girdle".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:17
verses.text: And as Wisdom sent the apostles, saying, "Go ye into all the world and preach the Gospel," so, too, the Holy Spirit says: "Separate Me Barnabas and Saul for the work whereunto I have called them".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:18
verses.text: And so being sent forth by the Holy Spirit, as the Scripture points out farther on, they were distinguished in nothing from the other apostles, as though they were sent in one way by God the Father, in another way by Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:19
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:20
verses.text: Lastly, Paul having been sent by the Spirit, was both a vessel of election on  Christ's part, and himself relates that God wrought in him, saying: "For He that wrought for Peter unto the apostleship of the circumcision, wrought for me also unto the Gentiles".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:21
verses.text: Since, then, the Same wrought in Paul Who wrought in Peter, it is certainly evident that, since the Spirit wrought in Paul, the Holy Spirit wrought also in Peter.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:22
verses.text: But Peter himself testifies that God the Father wrought in him, as it is stated in the Acts of the Apostles that Peter rose up and said to them: "Men and brethren, ye know that a good while ago God made choice amongst us that the Gentiles should hear the word of the Gospel from my mouth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:23
verses.text: See, then, in Peter God wrought the grace of preaching.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:24
verses.text: And who would dare to deny the operation of Christ in him, since he was certainly elected and chosen by Christ, when the Lord said: "Feed My lambs".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:25
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:26
verses.text: The operation, then, of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit is one, unless perchance you, who deny the oneness of the same operation upon the Apostle, think this; that the Father and the Spirit wrought in Peter, in whom the Son had wrought, as if the operation of the Son by no means sufficed for him to the attainment of the grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:27
verses.text: And so the strength of the Father, of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit being as it were joined and brought together, the work was manifold, lest the operation of Christ alone should be too weak to establish Peter.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:28
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:29
verses.text: And not only in Peter is there found to be one operation of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit, but also in all the apostles the unity of the divine operation, and a certain authority over the dispensations of heaven.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:30
verses.text: For the divine operation works by the power of a command, not in the execution of a ministry; for God, when He works, does not fashion anything by toil or art, but "He spake and they were made".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:31
verses.text: He said, "Let there be light, and there was light," for the effecting of the work is comprised in the commandment of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:32
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:33
verses.text: We can, then, easily find, if we will consider, that this royal power is by the witness of the Scriptures attributed to the Holy Spirit; and it will be made clear that all the apostles were not only disciples of Christ, but also ministers of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:34
verses.text: As also the teacher of the Gentiles tells us, when he says: "God hath set some in the Church, first apostles, secondarily prophets, thirdly teachers; then miracles, the gift of healings, helps, governments, divers kinds of tongues".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:35
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:36
verses.text: See, God set apostles, and set prophets and teachers, gave the gift of healings, which you find above to be given by the Holy Spirit; gave divers kinds of tongues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:37
verses.text: But yet all are not apostles, all are not prophets, all are not teachers.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:38
verses.text: Not all, says he, have the gift of healings, nor do all, says he, speak with tongues.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:39
verses.text: For the whole of the divine gifts cannot exist in each several man; each, according to his capacity, receives that which he either desires or deserves.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:40
verses.text: But the power of the Trinity, which is lavish of all graces, is not like this weakness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:41
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:42
verses.text: Lastly, God set apostles.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:43
verses.text: Those whom God set in the Church, Christ chose and ordained to be apostles, and sent them into the world, saying: "Go ye into all the world, and preach the Gospel to the whole creation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:44
verses.text: He that shall believe and be baptized shall be saved, but he that believeth not shall be damned.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:45
verses.text: And these signs shall follow them that believe.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:46
verses.text: In My Name shall they cast out devils, they shall speak with new tongues, they shall take up serpents, and if they shall drink any deadly thing, it shall not hurt them, they shall lay hands on the sick, and they shall recover".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:47
verses.text: You see the Father and Christ also set teachers in the Churches; and as the Father gives the gift of healings, so, too, does the Son give; as the Father gives the gift of tongues, so, too, has the Son also granted it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:48
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:49
verses.text: In like manner we have heard also above concerning the Holy Spirit, that He too grants the same kinds of graces.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:50
verses.text: For it is said: "To one is given through the Spirit the gift of healings, to another divers kinds of tongues, to another prophecy".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:51
verses.text: So, then, the Spirit gives the same gifts as the Father, and the Son also gives them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:52
verses.text: Let us now learn more expressly what we have touched upon above, that the Holy Spirit entrusts the same office as the Father and the Son, and appoints the same persons; since Paul said: "Take heed to yourselves, and to all the flock in the which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers to rule the Church of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:53
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:54
verses.text: There is, then, unity of authority, unity of appointment, unity of giving.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:55
verses.text: For if you separate appointment and power, what cause was there [for maintaining] that those whom Christ appointed as apostles, God the Father  appointed, and the Holy Spirit appointed? unless, perhaps, as if sharing a possession or a right, They, like men, were afraid of legal prejudice, and therefore the operation was divided, and the authority distributed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:56
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:57
verses.text: These things are narrow and paltry, even between men, who for the most part, although they do not agree in action, yet agree in will.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:58
verses.text: So that a certain person being asked what a friend is, answered, "A second self".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:59
verses.text: If, then, a man so defined a friend as to say, he was a second self, that is to say, through a oneness of love and good-will, how much more ought we to esteem the oneness of Majesty, in the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost, when by the same operation and divine power, either the unity, or certainly that which is more, the , as it is called in Greek, is expressed, for  signifies "the same," so that the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit have the same; so that to have the same will and the same power does not arise from the affection of the will, but inheres in the substance of the Trinity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:60
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:61
verses.text: This is the inheritance of apostolic faith and devotion, which one may observe also in the Acts of the Apostles.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:62
verses.text: Therefore Paul and Barnabas obeyed the commands of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:63
verses.text: And all the apostles obeyed, and forthwith ordained those whom the Spirit had ordered to be separated: "Separate Me," said He, "Barnabas and Saul".

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:64
verses.text: Do you see the authority of Him Who commands? Consider the merit of those who obey.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:65
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:66
verses.text: Paul believed, and because he believed he cast off the zeal of a persecutor, and gained a crown of righteousness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:67
verses.text: He believed who used to make havoc of the Churches; but being converted to the faith, he preached in the Spirit that which the Spirit commanded.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:68
verses.text: The Spirit anointed His champion, and having shaken off the dust of unbelief, presented him as an insuperable conqueror of the unbelievers to various assemblies of the ungodly, and trained him by many sufferings for the prize of his high calling in Christ Jesus.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:69
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:70
verses.text: Barnabas also believed, and obeyed because he believed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:71
verses.text: Therefore, being chosen by the authority of the Holy Spirit, Which came on him abundantly, as a special sign of his merits, he was not unworthy of so great a fellowship.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:72
verses.text: For one grace shone in these whom one Spirit had chosen.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:73
Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:74
verses.text: Nor was Paul inferior to Peter, though the latter was the foundation of the Church, and the former a wise builder knowing how to make firm the footsteps of the nations who believed; Paul was not, I say, unworthy of the fellowship of the apostles, but is easily comparable with the first, and second to none.

verses.name: Ambrose: On the Holy Spirit Book II 13:75
verses.text: For he who knows not that he is inferior makes himself equal.
